Description: GDP per capita of each country in terms of Purchasing power parity (PPP). This is the extent to which GDP contributes to calculating the Happiness Score. Gdp per capita is the Gross domestic product divided by the population of each country, whose goal is to calculate the value of goods and services to which each member of the economy has access. This measure of happiness focuses on the economic aspect of life; production and income.

Equal to the residual of regressing the national average of the binary question “ Have you donated money to a charity in the past month?” on GDP per capita, to estimate the extent to which Generosity contributes to the calculation of the Happiness Score

An estimation of the extent to which Family contributes to the World happiness score. This is equal to the country's average binary response (0, 1) to the Gallup World Poll (GWP) survey question: "If you were in trouble, do you have relatives or friends you can count on to help you whenever you need them, or not?"
The national average of binary answers (0, 1) to the GWP question: “  “Are you satisfied or dissatisfied with your freedom to choose what you do with your life?”

The measurement of which trust contributes to the calculation score. The perception of corruption is based on the average of two binary GDP survey questions: “Is corruption widespread throughout the government or not?” and “Is corruption widespread within businesses or not?”. The corruption perception is an individual response to their overall perception of corruption.

Based on estimating healthy life expectancies at birth from data extracted from the World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global Health Observatory data repository and World development indicators, Health.Life.Expectancy is the extent to which Life expectancy contributes to world happiness.
Each country is measured against a hypothetical nation called Dystopia. Dystopia has the lowest world’s lowest national averages for each of the six values calculated.
